title: Strictly Come Dancing fans call for BBC to release voting results
text:
Dev and Dianne were completely devastated (Picture: BBC/ SCD

METROGRAB)

Strictly Come Dancing fans have launched a petition in hopes of forcing the BBC to release the voting results from Sunday night’s show after Dev Griffin was evicted.

Radio 1 DJ Dev and dance partner Dianne Buswell were voted off the show, leaving viewers and judges reeling from shock – even days after it happened (we still can’t believe it).

Fans were especially not happy when the duo ended up in the bottom two, performing the dance-off against Viscountess Emma Weymouth and Aljaz Skorjanec.

Dianne was seen holding onto Dev as she broke down in tears on the dancefloor during their last dance together, before the other competitors flocked to be with her in a group hug.

The news left the audience and their fellow competitors in disbelief when their names were called out, with many taking to social media to share their surprise at the decision – and now a petition has even been set up.

The online petition accuses the four judges of scoring contestants ‘erratically’ and claims that the ‘voting phone lines failed’ for some contestants and not others, which they believe resulted in the shock dance-off.

Sorry, the video was not found

‘The voting phone lines failed for some contestants and not others.

‘Meanwhile, the judges on the night seemed to be ignoring all technical competence of celeb contestants and handing out scores randomly, most likely at the demand of the producers, to keep the less talented dancers in the competition.

‘Strictly is a national institution and its viewers deserve not to have their intelligence insulted in this way. Trust has been destroyed and the only way to rebuild it is to provide some transparency.

‘Release vote volumes by contestant for both phone and online, film a special ITT in which the judges explain their irrational scoring, release a statement from the producers to reassure public that they do not seek to influence results in any way and provide a clear policy statement regarding pro dancers use of social media and the extent to which it is controlled by the production team.’

As of Tuesday, October 16, the petition has reached 167 signatures.

You can sign the petition here.

Metro.co.uk contacted the BBC but they declined to comment.
